question: Determine the truth value of ∀n(n + 1 > n) if the domain consists of all real numbers.
explanation: There are no elements in the domain for which the statement is false.

question: Let P(x) denote the statement “x = x + 7.” What is the truth value of the quantification ∃xP(x), where the domain consists of all real numbers?
explanation: Because P(x) is false for every real number x, the existential quantification of Q(x), which is ∃xP(x), is false.

question: Let R (x) denote the statement “x > 2.” What is the truth value of the quantification ∃xR(x), having domain as real numbers?
explanation: Because “x > 2” is sometimes true—for instance, when x = 3–the existential quantification of R(x), which is ∃xR(x), is true.

question: ”Everyone wants to learn cosmology.” This argument may be true for which domains?
options: a) All students in your cosmology class
b) All the cosmology learning students in the world
explanation: Domain may be limited to your class or may be whole world both are good as it satisfies universal quantifier.

question: Let domain of m includes all students, P (m) be the statement “m spends more than 2 hours in playing polo”. Express ∀m ¬P (m) quantification in English.
options: a) A student is there who spends more than 2 hours in playing polo
b) There is a student who does not spend more than 2 hours in playing polo
c) All students spends more than 2 hours in playing polo
